review_blob:
Very floral aroma for me.
Bright golden color. Half inch head that dissipates quickly.
Medium to heavy sweet. Too sweet for a Tripel, in my opinion.
I didnt care for the after taste.
Just ok.

Interesting beer. A combination Belgian strong Ale and IPA. The aroma is pleasant and leans toward the IPA. The taste starts off as a Belgian Dubbel or Strong Ale and the the hops arrive, nicely. This beer poured a copper color With very little head. This is a medium bodied beer. It seems light for the high, 8.3% alcohol content. Limited carbonation. Overall, its been fun and interesting. A nice change of pace.

Lovely aromatic appeal. Musky woody aroma typical of a Belgian Quad. Nice malty essence.
Beautiful dark Quad color, brown heading toward black. Nice one inch head. Lacing lingers on the sides of the glass.
Medium sweet, lightly bitter taste. Hint og Belgian sour, bur barely. A bit of alcohol sate upfront but I liked it.
Danced nicely on my tongue. Long finish and remains pleasant all the way through.
Overall, really, really good. My son gave my this for Christmas as its one of his fav breweries. Thank you Michael. Will def drink it again. Good job Sly Fox.

What a find this holiday season. Aroma is delicious with the malty, earthy and heavenly scents expected of a St Bernardus. Pours a dark brown with a nice one inch head that lingers on the side of the glass. The taste is strong, lightly sweet, malty with hint of raisin or fig. Almost has a slight chocolate tone. Danced on my tongue as all of the St Bernardus brews do. Overall, wonderful. I admit it, Im totally biased in favor of the St Bernardus beers.

Its good. But I expected it to be great. Glad I got it at my local Wegmans and didnt drive to the brewery. Malty as a Belgian should be. Descent aroma. The color is spot on as a brown. But more thin in appearance than it ought to be. Less head than a Belgian should have. Taste is complex, sweet, malty, lightly sour. Pleasant on the palate but again, the thinness leaves something to be desired here. Overall, drinkable and tasty. For the money, I would buy a St Bernardus.
On the right track for the Belgian thing. Comes up a little short. Appearance is good, dark brown. Pleasant aroma. Good coating of glass. Light on taste. Neds more time bottle fermenting.
Copper colored. Doesnt coat the glass like a Belgian. GREAT hop aroma. Hoppy in a pleasant way. Refreshing, powerful and complex. I like it. And Im not a hoppy beer guy. That says a lot!

This is "my favorite beer in whole wide world." Seriously, it is. Im biased. I spent a day and night at the brewery in March this year. Ive had this at the brewery itself, in bars in Belgium, in bars in the US and at home. I love it.

The aroma ia the only category in which I didnt give it a perfect score. I gave it 9 out of 10. The aroma is pleasant. Their are hints of fig, malt, goodness. Only Rochefort may have a better aroma.

This beer pours a brown, hazy chocolate like color. The head is off white and stands an inch high. The head lingers and coats the glass on its way down.

The taste is heavenly. I get figs, sweetness, fruity (but not too much so) and malty. Very limited alcohol taste for such a high alcohol brew. It dances on the tongue and is warm going down. The entire mouth regals with pleasure.

I love this beer. Its the overall most wonderful beer in my beer universe.

Im drinking this in a glass purchased at the brewery and the beer is bottle conditioned. Ive had this on tap only once, in Philadelphia. And I didnt like it. Something was lost in the kegging. Or, this bar, which I wont name, had bad keg lines. It wasnt as good as Im used to. But since Ive had it at the brewery itself, maybe Im more familiar with it than most.

Pleasantly strong hoppy aroma. Great American hop aroma and taste upfront.

Pours a nice copper color with a generous head that coats the sides of the glass throughout the drink.

Just enough buttering hops. I dont love the IPA style and this is not quite in IPA territory. Its medium bitter and pleasant.

Perfect carbonation on the lips and tongue. Finish is only slightly bitter. Quite refreshing.

Overall, very good. Refreshing, tasty and easy to drink.

I really want to like this beer. But Im only so-so on it. Im drinking it now. I havent rated it previously because I really wanted to gie it a chance.

The aroma is the best part of this beer. The aroma reminds me so much of my travels in Belgium. But thats the best of this beer. Its downhill from there. The head disappears rapidly, by the second sip. The tase is just odd. Dare I say that the Tripel that I brewed 6 months is beter (my wife agrees). I find myself searching my palate for a deScription of the flavors. Its confusing. Overall, I give this a disappointing 10 out of 20.

So sorry Weyerbacher. I love many of your other beers. I wanted to like this. At least its better than Flying Fish Exit 4.

If I didnt know what it was, I would swear it was from Belgium. Pours dark chocolate brown with a strong head that laces the glass through the drink.

Aroma is perfect for an Abbey Dubbel.

Tase is pleasant. Perfect for the style. Great balance of malt and fig. Just enough sweet and just enough fizz.

Surprisingly wonderful. Ive only tried their Tripel previously. This is really good. I will get it again.

This beer pours medium dark with a creamy tan head. The head doesnt last too long but it coats the glass throughout the drink. 

Aroma is almost like a quad. Good carbonation. 

The taste is pleasant, not too sweet, not too sour. The alcohol is well hidden and its 11%. Enjoyable on the front of the tongue and the rear.

Most enjoyable. I only bought two btls at the brewery. Wish now that I had gotten more. Guess this means I need to go back!

About this Brewery: For an American Brewery, they really do a great job with the Belgian style. I must credit a guy named "Joe," from Montgomery County, PA whom I met at Beer Circus in Belgium. He told me to got to Weyerbacher and he was spot on. I have Joes tele number and I must call him and buy him a brew. This brewery bottle conditions these beers. Everything that I have sampled from this brewery has been great.

Well, this is my first time with this. It came so highly acclaimed, I had to try it. I wish I wouldnt be so hard on it, so Ill do my best to be kind. It really isnt my thing, and I thought it would be.

Pours dark with no head to speak of. What little head there is, however, lingers on the side of the glass nicely. I like a beer with head.

The taste is initially sweet, followed quickly by sour. Not quite "sour patch kids" sour, but sour.

Palate? I couldnt wait to have a different beer to get the taste out of my mouth.

Overall I just didnt like it. That being said, I like the beers at a sour beer brewery in Brussels even less. So its not the worst Ive ever had. But I just didnt like it. But in all fairness, I think I just dont like the style. Frankly, I bumped my score up a little because I didnt want to be cruel to a beer that the brewery and family are very proud of.

Pours with no head. Nice copper color. Totally flat with no evidence of CO2. How they got it out of the keg? I dont know.
Sour finish. Sucks.

Wonderful aroma of malt, chocolate and figs.

Pours a dark brown with a one finger size head. The head lingers, especially around the rim for the duration.

Taste is delicious. The sweetness is appealing, and I dont really care for sweet beers. The sweet fades fast giving way to a dry, rich taste. Front of tongue and back are superior.

Overall, a slendid drink.

Pours a hazy brown with 1 inch head.

Deserving little brother to the ABT 12.

Pleasant, aromatic, feels great on the tongue.

Would be the number one beer in any other brewerys line of beers.

Mellow aroma for a tripel. I, personally, think of this more as a "blonde" than a "tripel." But thats just me. Very pleasant, balanced aroma... not too sweet, not too malty.

Pours a dark golden color with a solid one inch head. Essence of the head lingers through the entire drink. Moderately hazy, somewhere between a Wheat Beer and a Westy Blonde.

Pleasant upfront taste. More bitter than other tripels but in a nice way. Solid taste on the back of the tongue with no lingering bitterness. Great mix of sweet and bitter.

Average carbonation, smooth texture, medium/light bodied with a delightful finish.

Overall I love this. Its my second favorite Blonde Belgian.

Drinking this right now. The aroma is pungent. Lemongrass gone bad.

Pours a cloudy golden color. Head disappears immediately.

The taste is odd. This beer cant make up its mind. Is it a Tripel? Is it a simple Ale? Tastes like a brewer tried too hard.

Overall it is thoroughly under whelming. I was looking forward to this.

Wow, what a beer. The aroma betrays the high alcohol content. Not as sweet as some tripels.

Arrives at the table at Staminee de Garre a bright golden color with a big white head that lingers and coats the sides of the glass. Typically hazy as a Tripel should be.

The taste is smooth and rich. Numerous flavors appear with no fighting. Only lightly sweet.

The feeling of the hear on the lips and tongue lasts. Overall, this is pleasant and delicious. Everything I had heard and hoped for.

Does "Heaven in a Glass" serve as a critique?

Pours dark; Great head that last; Flavorful til the last drop.

Malty; special; dances on the tongue; pleasant upfront and after.

Absolutely a dream and everything I hope it would be. Couldnt bring it back home as it wasnt available. Went back two days in a row just to have it when I could.

Aroma is stronger than I expected. Pleasant enough. Not too malty, not too hoppy.

Golden orange appearance and much more hazy than I expect from a "pale" ale. Head disappeared fast. No coating the sides of the glass.

The taste is a little sour but just a little. I expected an 
everyday ale" and this just isnt it. Not as refreshing as I hoped.

Palate? Does boring fit? I might not even finish it.

Overall I find this beer annoying. I bought it at the brewery yesterday after a tour. I was surprised that they force carbonate all of their beers. No bottle conditioning here. I thought my son was coming over for Easter dinner (he isnt) and I know he likes Flying Fish. I dont like to be negative but this just isnt for me. In a word... disappointing.

I brought this beer back from St sixtus in Watou three weeks ago. Drank the first one last night. The aroma is very pleasant and is similar to other Trappist Doubles. The aroma grows stronger and more pleasant as you drink it (slowly), allowing it to warm. Malt is the primary aroma with no hop presence. No yeast evidence either as would be the case with a Tripel.

The looks like a cup of coffee. It is rich and dark with a beautiful 2.5 inch light brown head that lessens but lingers for the duration. The head coats the sides of the goblet.

The taste is surprisingly strong of alcohol early in the drink. More so than the Westy 12. This surprised me. This diminished fairly quickly. The flavors dance on the tongue and are equally enjoyed in the rear of the mouth. The flavor strengthens and gets even better throughout the drink. I hated to see it end. The texture was typical Trappist, smooth, creamy and full.

Overall I really like this. I resisted having a second as I brought home a limited supply. I also want to age a few bottles a bit and see what I get.

Ive had this beer in the U.S at Theresas Other Side in Wayne, PA and at Het Waterhuis, Gent. I like it more than some of the other reviewers.
Pours a dark copper color, somewhere between clear and hazy. Nice two finger off white head.
Taste is strong at upfront and the alcohol comes through. It mellows as I drink it and a subtle sweetness appears. Limited bitterness. Pleasant on the palate. Soft carbonation. Finishes very smooth. I like it. Had it at home and in Gent en vat both places. Wish I could get it in the bottle for my home.
